headline: Bitcoin Holds Ground as Ethereum Retreats

sections.the_session:
• Bitcoin traded in a narrow band around $92,500 through the US session, holding essentially flat over 24 hours despite broader risk-off sentiment — the kind of consolidation that suggests neither conviction nor capitulation from current holders.

• Ethereum underperformed notably, shedding 3.2% to $3,231 and widening the performance gap with Bitcoin that has defined recent weeks; the ETH/BTC ratio continues to compress as capital rotates toward the market leader.

• Bitcoin dominance ticked up to 57.2%, reinforcing the flight-to-quality dynamic within crypto that typically characterizes uncertain macro environments — altcoins are being treated as higher-beta plays to shed, not accumulate.

• Solana slipped 0.9% to $136, a modest decline relative to Ethereum but still marking its third consecutive session of lower highs — the momentum that carried it through November appears to be cooling.

• Total market capitalization contracted marginally to $3.23 trillion, with volume patterns suggesting institutional desks are largely on the sidelines ahead of year-end positioning decisions.
sections.the_session_title: Bitcoin Steady While ETH Gives Back Gains
sections.the_macro:
• The dollar index held near two-year highs heading into Wednesday's session, maintaining pressure on risk assets including crypto as markets price in a more hawkish Fed trajectory through 2025 — strong currency typically correlates with subdued Bitcoin appetite.

• Treasury yields remained elevated with the 10-year hovering above 4.4%, reflecting persistent inflation concerns that have tempered expectations for aggressive rate cuts next year; the higher-for-longer narrative continues to weigh on duration-sensitive assets.

• European markets closed mixed as traders digested weak German business sentiment data, with the DAX slipping 0.3% — the eurozone's economic malaise provides little support for global risk appetite.

• Oil prices stabilized around $69 per barrel after Monday's sharp decline, removing one source of volatility but doing little to shift the broader macro picture that has kept institutional crypto allocators cautious.

• Gold traded flat near $2,620, suggesting haven demand remains muted despite geopolitical tensions — a dynamic that typically correlates with range-bound Bitcoin behavior.
sections.the_macro_title: Fed Minutes Loom as Dollar Strength Persists

north_america.name: North America
north_america.content:
• US spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded modest net inflows of approximately $275 million on Tuesday, with BlackRock's IBIT capturing the lion's share at $186 million while Grayscale's GBTC saw continued but slowing outflows of $32 million — the asymmetry suggests institutional preference has firmly settled on the newer, lower-fee products.

• The SEC remained quiet on pending crypto matters as the agency enters its final weeks under Chair Gensler, though industry observers note several enforcement actions appear to be in advanced stages — the regulatory interregnum creates uncertainty that may be suppressing trading activity.

• MicroStrategy shares traded lower by 2.4% despite Bitcoin's stability, suggesting the leverage premium investors have assigned to the stock may be compressing as direct ETF access becomes the preferred institutional vehicle.

• Canadian Bitcoin ETFs reported steady accumulation through Purpose and Evolve products, with combined AUM approaching CAD $4.2 billion — the northern market continues to demonstrate consistent retail demand even as US products dominate headlines.

• Texas energy regulators approved expanded grid participation for Bitcoin miners under new demand-response protocols, a policy development that strengthens the state's position as North America's mining hub while addressing grid stability concerns.

central_america.name: Central America
central_america.content:
• El Salvador's Bitcoin holdings remained unchanged at approximately 5,950 BTC according to government disclosures, with President Bukele's administration notably quieter on Bitcoin purchases since the US election — a shift from the regular buying announcements that characterized earlier periods.

• Remittance flows through Bitcoin rails in Guatemala showed continued growth according to regional fintech data, though dollar-denominated stablecoins remain the dominant crypto vehicle for cross-border payments in the corridor.

• Panama's crypto regulatory framework remains in legislative limbo as the national assembly prioritizes other economic matters, leaving exchanges operating under informal guidance — a contrast with the clearer frameworks emerging in South America.

south_america.name: South America
south_america.content:
• Brazil's central bank advanced its CBDC pilot program with new retail payment integrations announced for the Drex digital real, a development that could reshape how Brazilians interact with digital assets — though crypto advocates note CBDCs and decentralized assets serve fundamentally different purposes.

• Argentine peso weakness accelerated past 1,000 to the dollar on parallel markets, driving renewed stablecoin demand on local exchanges; USDT premiums in Buenos Aires reached 3.2% above global rates, reflecting the persistent dollar hunger that makes Argentina crypto's most compelling emerging market case.

• Colombia's financial superintendent issued updated guidance permitting banks to offer crypto custody services through regulated third parties, a measured liberalization that opens institutional pathways while maintaining oversight — Bancolombia and Davivienda are reportedly exploring partnerships.

• Venezuelan adoption patterns showed continued reliance on peer-to-peer Bitcoin trading as formal exchange access remains limited by sanctions and capital controls; LocalBitcoins alternatives have absorbed much of this volume following that platform's closure.

• Mercado Bitcoin, Brazil's largest exchange, reported record November trading volumes driven by retail interest in Bitcoin's post-election rally, though December activity has moderated alongside the broader market consolidation.

image_keywords: Manhattan skyline, golden sunset, Hudson River, warm evening glow
